Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2014 02:56AM mz_mes wrote: Wow.  You sound like a very hard working women.   Maybe the more physically demanding the job the harder it is to maintain at the same pace during rads.   I've got a desk job -- with lots of computer, web meetings and teleconferences so I haven't missed a day at work.   I have had to leave a few web meetings a few minutes early and joined some a bit late but overall managing to squeeze it all in.    Today at my rads appointments there were several folks in the patient lounge waiting for their appointments when I arrived.  I've got regular teleconferences on Thursdays so I finish that in the waiting room.   I hope the others don't mind.  No one says anything.       The machine had to be reset and so they got backed up.  It was the first appointment where I had to wait more than a minute or two and where there was more than one other person waiting.   So far I've been pleasantly surprised with how smoothly the appointments go - even when I see the doctor it was quick.  Even with the little wait today it only took an additional 15 minutes.  I cannot complain!       I have cut back on my exercise intensity and duration since starting rads, though my docs did say to keep exercising as it helps a lot.    I try to do something everyday but am happy if I move for 30 minutes --- even just gentle stretching.   I don't know if I could manage the cleaning job but you are accustomed to it so I'll bet you'll be fine.  You do have an excuse (in your case two with the Lyme) to back off a bit!  Best of luck juggling it all.   Sounds like maybe a nap is in order after you get done with work though.
